facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated January 13, 1969 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court, at Chandigarh, in P.A. No. 6 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2129 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the order dated January 13, 1969 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court, at Chandigarh, in P.A. No. 6 of 1969. Sen and G. D. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant joined the Punjab Irrigation Department as a temporary Engineer in 1939 and became an Executive Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant joined the Punjab Irrigation Department as a temporary Engineer in 1939 and in companyrse of time became an Executive Engineer in that department.

facts.text: In December 1954 the appellant was arrested in connection with a case under Sec. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act registered against K. R. Sharma.

anchor.surface_text: In December, 19 4 he was arrested in companynection with a case under Sec. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act which had been registered against one K. R. Sharma, Superintending Engineer,

facts.text: Appellant was enlarged on bail after arrest.

anchor.surface_text: with whom the appellant had been working as a Personal Assistant. The appellant was, however, enlarged on bail.

facts.text: Appellant was suspended with effect from 13 December 1954 and departmental proceedings started.

anchor.surface_text: About the same, time the appellant was suspended with effect from 13 December 1954 and certain departmental proceedings were started, against him.

facts.text: In November 1956 the appellant was served with a charge sheet under Rule 7.2 of the Punjab Civil Services Punishment and Appeal Rules with two charges (1a and 1b) of taking illegal gratification.

anchor.surface_text: In November 1956 the appellant was served with a charge sheet under Rule 7.2 of the Punjab Civil Services  Punishment and Appeal  Rules, There, were, two distinct charges

facts.text: On 18 December 1956 the appellant submitted a reply to the chargesheet.

anchor.surface_text: On 18 December 1956 the appellant submitted a reply to the chargesheet to which he added certain supplementary replies between MAY and July 195?.

facts.text: Enquiry Officer appointed in October 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Government, it appears, appointed an Enquiry Officer as late as October, 1957.

facts.text: On 18 February 1958 the appellant was reverted from Executive Engineer under suspension to Assistant Engineer under suspension.

anchor.surface_text: On 18 February 1958 the appellant was., reverted from the post of Executive Engineer  under suspension  to that of an Assistant Engineer  under suspension .

facts.text: In May 1958 Government deferred enquiry on Charge 1b until decision on Charge 1a.

anchor.surface_text: In May, 1958 Government decided to defer the enquiry in respect of Charge 1  b  until there was a decision in regard to Charge 1 a ,

facts.text: In October 1958 Enquiry Officer submitted report exonerating appellant on Charge 1a.

anchor.surface_text: In, October, 1958 the Enquiry Officer submitted to Government a report in respect of Charge 1 a  which exonerated the appellant companypletely.

facts.text: Government appointed another Enquiry Officer for Charge 1b after six months wait.

anchor.surface_text: The Government then waited for another six months before appointing another Enquiry Officer to companyduct the enquiry in regard to Charge 1 b .

facts.text: Appellant requested copy of first Enquiry Officer report on Charge 1a, but Government declined.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, it appears, asked Government on more than one occasion to supply him with a companyy of the report of the first Enquiry Officer in respect of Charge 1  a .

facts.text: In December 1960 the criminal case against appellant ended in discharge.

anchor.surface_text: In December, 1960 the criminal case which had been Started against the appellant in 1954 ended in discharge of the appellant.

facts.text: On 19 April 1961 appellant was dismissed from service based on second Enquiry Officer report on Charge 1b.

anchor.surface_text: On 19 April 1961 the appellant was dismissed from service on the basis of a report of the second Enquiry Officer regarding Charge 1 b .

facts.text: Dismissal order quashed by High Court in March 1963.

anchor.surface_text: This order of dismissal was, however, quashed in March, 1963 by the High Court of Punjab and Haryana.

facts.text: Appellant reinstated and suspended again in May 1963; third Enquiry Officer appointed for Charge 1b.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was, thereafter, reinstated and forthwith placed under another order of suspension in May, 1963. A third Enquiry Officer was appointed simultaneously

facts.text: In February 1965 appellant got decree in civil suit for balance pay/allowances during suspension and quashing reversion order.

anchor.surface_text: In February, 1965 the appellant got a decree in a civil suit by which he was allowed to recover the balance of his pay and allowances

facts.text: On 15 December 1965 new Enquiry Officer appointed replacing earlier one.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing happened until 15 December 1965 when, once again Government appointed a new Enquiry Officer to, replace the earlier officer

facts.text: In January 1966 appellant reinstated as Executive Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1966 the appellant was reinstated as Executive Engineer

facts.text: In October 1966 the entire enquiry against appellant was withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: and in October, the same year, the entire enquiry against the appellant was withdrawn.

facts.text: On 26 October 1966 Government served fresh Show Cause notice proposing censure for unsatisfactory 1956 explanation.

anchor.surface_text: On the companytrary, however, on 26 October 1966 Government served a fresh Show Cause numberice on the appellant by which the appellant was told

facts.text: Appellant requested copy of S.D. Khanna's statement under Sec. 164 CrPC, denied on 24 November 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately upon receipt of the said Show Cause numberice the appellant asked for a companyy of the statement made by one S. D Khanna, Sub-Divisional Officer

facts.text: On 16 December 1966 appellant submitted reply to Show Cause notice.

anchor.surface_text: On 24 November 1966, however, Secretary to the Government of Haryana turned down the appellants request for a companyy of Khannas statement.

facts.text: On 27 February 1967 Government imposed penalty of censure on appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On 27 February 1967 the Government passed an order imposing the penalty of censure on the appellant.

facts.text: On 27 February 1967 order under Rule 7.3(3) withholding pay beyond subsistence allowance for suspension period 31 May 1963 to 6 January 1966, treated as duty for other purposes.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day another order was companymunicated to the appel- lant by which the Governor of Haryana had directed that under Rule 7.3 3

facts.text: In November 1967 appellant filed writ petition in High Court challenging two orders of 27 February 1967.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, however, in November, 1967 the appellant had filed a writ petition in the High Court of Punjab and Haryana challenging the validity

facts.text: Writ petition dismissed by Single Judge on 6 November 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was dismissed by a Single Judge of the High Court on 6 November 1968.

facts.text: Division Bench dismissed appeal in limine; order dated 13 January 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then went on appeal before a Division Bench of the High Court. The appeal was, however, dismissed in limine.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court on 3 October 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Upon being refused a certificate for appeal to this Court, the appellant asked for special leave which was granted to him on 3 October 1969.

facts.text: Court held Show Cause notice of 26 October 1966 was vague, no reasonable opportunity to reply.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companyplaint about the Show Cause numberice of 26 October 1966 is one that has to be accepted as substantial.

facts.text: Court quashed censure order of 27 February 1967 for lack of opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: companysequently the order of censure passed on him is bad and liable to be struck down.

facts.text: Court held second order of 27 February 1967 under Rule 7.3 passed without opportunity, quashed.

anchor.surface_text: the order of 27 February 1967 which withheld from the appellant any payment in excess of the subsistence allowance

facts.text: Appeal succeeds, High Court judgment set aside, orders quashed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal succeeds. The judgment and order of the High Court- are set aside. The orders dated 27 February 1967
under Art. 226 of the Constitution of India was dismissed.

issues.text: whether the appellant did not get a reasonable opportunity to reply to the Show Cause notice dated 26 October 1966 on the basis of which he had been censured by the Government inasmuch as the notice was too vague to enable him to give an effective reply

anchor.surface_text: First, it was contended that the appellant did not get a reasonable opportunity to reply to the Show Cause notice dated 26 October 1966 on the basis of which he had been censured by the Government inasmuch as the notice was too vague to enable him to give an effective reply.

issues.text: whether the order of 27 February 1967 which withheld from the appellant any payment in excess of the subsistence allowance he had drawn during the period of his suspension was liable to be struck down on the ground that it had been passed without giving him any opportunity to make a representation against it

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was contended that the order of 27 February 1967 which withheld from the appellant any payment in excess of the subsistence allowance he had drawn during the period of his suspension was liable to be struck down on the ground that it had been passed without giving him any opportunity to make a representation against it.

arguments.claim: the appellant did not get a reasonable opportunity to reply to the Show Cause notice dated 26 October 1966 on the basis of which he had been censured by the Government inasmuch as the notice was too vague to enable him to give an effective reply

anchor.surface_text: First, it was contended that the appellant did not get a reasonable opportunity to reply to the Show Cause notice dated 26 October 1966 on the basis of which he had been censured by the Government inasmuch as the notice was too vague to enable him to give an effective reply.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of 18 December 1956 which is said to have been found unsatisfactory by Government was a reply number only to Charge 1  a  but also to Charge 1 b  of t

arguments.court_reasoning: Notice vague: does not specify which charge (1a exonerated or 1b), in what way explanation unsatisfactory, or materials relied on; essential to indicate precise scope and points for reply

arguments.claim: the order of 27 February 1967 which withheld from the appellant any payment in excess of the subsistence allowance he had drawn during the period of his suspension was liable to be struck down on the ground that it had been passed without giving him any opportunity to make a representation against it

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was contended that the order of 27 February 1967 which withheld from the appellant any payment in excess of the subsistence allowance he had drawn during the period of his suspension was liable to be struck down on the ground that it had been passed without giving him any opportunity to make a representation against it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ty companypetent to order the reinstatement shall companysider and make a specific order -  a regarding the pay and allowances to be paid to the Gover

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule 7.3 requires forming opinion on exoneration/unjustified suspension affecting pay; quasi-judicial, demands prior opportunity; charges withdrawn akin to exoneration

arguments.claim: since the appellant was aware of the charge and also aware of the reply he had given to the charges made against him, it was enough for Government to tell him that his answer was unsatisfactory

anchor.surface_text: We were told that since the appellant was aware of the charge and also aware of the reply he had given to the charges made against him, it was enough for Government to tell him that his answer was unsatisfactory. It was argued that since the Show Cause notice really pointed this out

court_response_anchor.surface_text: instated, he never got an opportunity to show to the appointing authority that his suspension had been unjustified and that he was entitled to full pa

arguments.court_reasoning: No hesitation in rejecting; notice too vague to permit effective dealing

arguments.claim: before passing an order under Rule 7.3, the authority concerned has to form an opinion as to whether the Government servant has been fully exonerated and, also, whether, in the case of suspension, the order of suspension was wholly unjustified

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that before passing an order under Rule 7.3, the authority concerned has to form an opinion as to whether the Government servant has been fully exonerated and, also, whether, in the case of suspension, the order of suspension waswholly unjustified.

arguments.claim: Reliance was placed upon the Judgment of this Court in M. Gopala Krishna Naidu v. State of Madhya Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed upon the Judgment of this Court in M. Gopala Krishna Naidu v. State of Madhya Pradesh . The appellant in that case had been exonerated of the charges framed against him in a departmental enquiry.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: efend himself against Charge 1  b . It will be remembered that in this case also the Government abandoned the proceedings against the appellant with r

arguments.court_reasoning: Ratio applies: order affects pay financially, requires objective consideration and opportunity; facts analogous as charges withdrawn

arguments.claim: since in M. Gopala Krishna Naidus case the proceedings had been dropped and the officer concerned reinstated, he never got an opportunity to show to the appointing authority that his suspension had been unjustified... while-in the instant case the appellant has already... received all reasonable opportunity

Gopala Krishna Naidus case the proceedings had been dropped and the officer concerned reinstated, he never got an opportunity to show to the appointing authority that his suspension had been unjustified and that he was entitled to full pay and allowances, while-in the instant case

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d clearly number been fully exonerated of the charges levied against him, it was open to Government to decide what period of absence from duty during

arguments.court_reasoning: No real difference in substance; appellant did not get opportunity on Charge 1b as proceedings abandoned/withdrawn

arguments.claim: Mr. Mahajan appearing for the State sought to rely... upon an unreported decision of this Court in the, State of Assam and Anr. v. Raghava Rajagopalachari

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mahajan appearing for the State sought to rely in this connection upon an unreported decision of this Court in the, State of Assam and Anr. v. Raghava Rajagopalachari . That case was a case dealing with Fundamental Rule 54 which is more or less similar to Rule 7.3

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ber been fully exonerated or to assume that the order of suspension was one which was number wholly unjustified.In that view of the matter, we do numb

arguments.court_reasoning: Does not apply; charges withdrawn made full exoneration impossible, unlike non-acquittal there

arguments.claim: the order regarding allowances was a mere consequential order and in passing such an order it was not necessary to give a hearing to the party affected by the order

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the Government that the order regarding allowances was a mere consequential order and in passing such an order it was not necessary to give a hearing to the party affected by the order.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ecessary to give a hearing to the party affected by the order. This Court, however, held that an order passed under Fundamental Rule, 54 is number alw

arguments.court_reasoning: Not mere consequential; consideration under Rule 7.3 objective function, duty to act judicially, requires opportunity

arguments.claim: an order passed under Fundamental Rule, 54 is not always a consequential order or a mere continuation of the departmental proceeding... companysideration under the Rule must be held to be an objective rather than a subjective function. The very nature of the function implies the duty to act judicially

anchor.surface_text: This Court, however, held that an order passed under Fundamental Rule, 54 is not always a consequential order or a mere continuation of the departmental proceeding taken against the employee. Since consideration under Fundamental Rule 54 depends on facts and circumstances in their entirety and since the order may result in pecuniary loss

arguments.claim: justice and fair play demand that the Government should have given the appellant a reasonable opportunity to show cause why an order affecting his pay and emoluments to his prejudice should not be made

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt in our minds that in this case also justice and fair play demand that the Government should have given the appellant a reasonable opportunity to show cause why an order affecting his pay and emoluments to his prejudice should not be made,

holdings.text: The Show Cause notice of 26 October 1966 was too vague to permit the appellant to deal with it effectively and consequently the order of censure passed on him is bad and liable to be struck down.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifestly clear that the Show Cause notice was too vague to permit the appellant to deal with. it effectively and that consequently the order of censure passed on him is bad and liable to be struck down.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice vaguely refers to 'charges and allegations' without specifying which (1a exonerated or 1b), in what way explanation unsatisfactory, or materials relied on; fails to indicate precise scope and points for reply, denying real opportunity to defend.

holdings.text: Before passing an order under Rule 7.3, the authority concerned has to form an opinion as to whether the Government servant has been fully exonerated and, also, whether, in the case of suspension, the order of suspension was wholly unjustified.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that before passing an order under Rule 7.3, the authority concerned has to form an opinion as to whether the Government servant has been fully exonerated and, also, whether, in the case of suspension, the order of suspension waswholly unjustified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Rule 7.3(2) distinguishes full exoneration/unjustified suspension entitling full pay from other cases; requires specific order on pay/allowances and duty period.

holdings.text: An order under Rule 7.3 is not a mere consequential order but requires a reasonable opportunity to show cause as it affects pay and emoluments, imposing a duty to act judicially.

anchor.surface_text: This Court, however, held that an order passed under Fundamental Rule, 54 is not always a consequential order or a mere continuation of the departmental proceeding taken against the employee. Since consideration under Fundamental Rule 54 depends on facts and circumstances in their entirety and since the order may result in pecuniary loss

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following M. Gopala Krishna Naidu precedent (analogous FR 54): consideration objective, depends on facts, results in financial prejudice, implies duty to act judicially and afford prior hearing per natural justice.

holdings.text: Withdrawal of departmental proceedings amounts to full exoneration where prior charge exonerated, making it impossible to deny full pay under Rule 7.3 or treat suspension as justified.

anchor.surface_text: This decision cannot apply to the instant case for the simple reason that Government, by withdrawing the proceedings initiated against the appellant in respect of Charge 1 b , made it impossible for the appellant to get himself fully exonerated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exoneration on Charge 1a + withdrawal of Charge 1b prevents finding of non-exoneration; distinguishes State of Assam case (no withdrawal, not acquitted); suspension unjustified.

holdings.text: The orders dated 27 February 1967 are quashed for breach of natural justice; appeal succeeds and High Court judgment set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal succeeds. The judgment and order of the High Court- are set aside. The orders dated 27 February 1967 impugned in the appellants petition before the High Court are quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both impugned orders invalid due to lack of reasonable opportunity; cumulative effect from prior holdings.

precedents.case_name: M. Gopala Krishna Naidu v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Order under Fundamental Rule 54 regarding pay and allowances for period of suspension after reinstatement requires opportunity to show cause as it is quasi-judicial function and breach of natural justice if not given
precedents.cited_holding: if an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed is not afforded, the order is liable to be struck down as invalid on the ground that it is one in breach of the principles of natural justice

precedents.cited_proposition: Under cl. (b) of Fundamental Rule 54, where government servant not honourably acquitted, authority may prescribe proportion of pay and allowances for absence period and treatment as duty
